sub_topic: Calculation of the mass of a substance deposited or dissolved during an electrochemical reaction
message_1: What mass of copper is deposited on a cathode when a current of 2.5 A passes through a solution of copper(II) sulphate for 30 minutes? (Given: Atomic mass of copper = 63.5 g/mol, Faraday constant = 96500 C/mol)
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use Faraday's laws of electrolysis. The mass of copper deposited on the cathode can be calculated using the following formula:

mass = (current × time × molar mass) / (n × Faraday constant)

where:
- mass is the mass of copper deposited (in grams)
- current is the electric current (in amperes)
- time is the duration of the electrolysis (in seconds)
- molar mass is the molar mass of copper (in grams per mole)
- n is the number of electrons involved in the redox reaction (in this case, 2 for the Cu²⁺ ion)
- Faraday constant is the charge of one mole of electrons (in coulombs per mole)

First, let's convert the time from minutes to seconds:

30 minutes × 60 seconds/minute = 1800 seconds

Now, we can plug the values into the formula:

mass = (2.5 A × 1800 s × 63.5 g/mol) / (2 × 96500 C/mol)

mass = (4500 C × 63.5 g/mol) / (193000 C/mol)

mass ≈ 1.47 g

So, approximately 1.47 grams of copper will be deposited on the cathode when a current of 2.5 A passes through a solution of copper(II) sulphate for 30 minutes.
